content: The text chunk focuses on reviewing and establishing policies for the Department of Defense investigative practices in response to allegations of sex-related offenses. The Secretary of Defense will review military criminal investigative organizations' practices regarding sex-related offenses and develop a uniform policy for recording investigation results. The Secretary of Defense will develop a policy for recording investigation results of sex-related offenses, considering methods used by nonmilitary law enforcement agencies. The term "sex-related offense" includes specific offenses under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Development of selection criteria for sexual assault response and prevention program managers, coordinators, and victim advocates. The qualifications for assignment to duty as a Sexual Assault Response and Prevention Program Manager, Coordinator, or Victim Advocate in the Department of Defense are outlined in an amendment to the Ike Skelton National Defense Authorization Act. The amendment to the Ike Skelton National Defense Authorization Act outlines the qualifications for members of the Armed Forces and civilian employees assigned to duty as Sexual Assault Response and Prevention Program Managers, Coordinators, and Victim Advocates. The Ike Skelton National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2011 specifies selection criteria for members of the Armed Forces and civilian employees in roles related to Sexual Assault Response and Prevention Program. SEC. 3. UNIFORM TRAINING AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS FOR SEXUAL ASSAULT PREVENTION AND RESPONSE PROGRAM. Section 585(a) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012 is amended to require the Secretary of Defense to develop a uniform curriculum for sexual assault prevention and response training by June 30, 2014. The Secretary of Defense is required to develop a uniform curriculum for sexual assault prevention and response training by June 30, 2014. This includes lesson plans to achieve core competencies and learning objectives. The training must be consistent and tailored for members of the Armed Forces and civilian employees of the Department of Defense.
